title: A Song of Old Hawai'i & The One They Call Hawai'i

By Andy Williams: There's the perfume of a million flowers
Clinging to the heart of old Hawai'i
There's a rainbow following the showers
Bringing me a part of old Hawai'i
And the hum of soft guitars
By Loeka Longakit: If I could be the ocean
Embracing all the land
If I could be the sunlight
That dries up all the sand
If I could be the lava
That flows to the sea
Then I would be the one they call Hawaii
Hawaii, Hawaii
If I could play the guitar
I'd play Hawaiian songs
If I could do the hula
I'd do it all day long
If I could be a koa canoe
I would float myself to sea
I guess I'd be the one they call Hawaii
Hawaii, Hawaii
If I could be the flowers
I'd turn into a lei
If I could be a rainbow
I'd make a…

English: Perfume in the air and rare flowers everywhere
And white shadows we could share at Waikīkī
A sky full of stars and soft far away guitars
It seems to be only a reverie
Night and you and blue Hawaiʻi
And you are heaven to me
Come with me while the moon is on the sea
The night is young and so are we
Dreams come true in blue Hawaiʻi
And mine could all come true
This magic night of nights with you
When I leave, I will take from this place the lei that we share
When I leave, I will breathe in the grace of this love in the air
And it will live, as long as I live
And with every song that I hear
I'll believe that my spirit still lives in the wind and the sea
And I'll breathe every memory of you as it wafts out to me
And I'll be here, as long as you're here
Ride on the songs you've been given
Fly back to us when you hear them, oh hear them
I have seen all the signs of my life as they daily unfold
I am pleased to have joined with you all in the dance of my soul
And I will feel as long as you feel
When I leave, oh when I leave

title: Hawaiian Lullaby
authors: Words by Hector Venegas & Peter Moon, music by Peter Moon

English: Where I live, there are rainbows
With life in the laughter of morning and starry nights
Where I live, there are rainbows
And flowers full of colors and birds filled with song
I can smile when it's raining
And touch the warmth of the sun
I hear children laughing in this place that I love
Where I live, there are rainbows
With life and the laughter of morning and starry nights

title: He Mele No Lilo
notes: Cody Pueo Pata CD "E Ho`i Nä Wai" Translated by Pueo Pata - Originally recorded by Hui Ohana with a later version by Dennis Pavao, research by Pueo Pata uncovered these lyrics. This poem refers to the booming and swelling seas of Kalapana that was finally destroyed by lava 1990.

Hawaiian: 'O Ka pua mae'ole i ka lā
Ka pua maila i ka mauna
I ka pali kapu o Ka'auea
Ea mai ke ali'i kia manu
Ua wehi i ka hulu o ka mamo
'O Ka pua mae'ole i ka lā
Ka pua maila i ka mauna
I ka pali kapu o Ka'auea
Ea mai ke ali'i kia manu
Ua wehi i ka hulu o ka mamo
He Inoa No Kalani Kalākaua Kulele
Ua lono ka uka o Hōlei,
Kuli wale, kuli wale i ka leo,
He leo no ke kai, ē.
English: It is Kalapana, the great-voiced sea,
Deafened, deafened indeed by the voice,
It is the voice of the sea
What fun it is to ride and sing
Oh, what fun it is to ride
In a one-horse open sleigh, hey
Oh, what fun it is to ride

Hawaiian: Aia i ka lehua popohe maʻu
Kele lele na kini manu i ka lehulehu
Huli kaʻiʻiwi i ka pua hiwahiwa
Iwalea ka manu i ka lehua, punono
Nolu pe ka lehua i ka lihau
Hau mai nei ka makani oluʻolu
Lu ke kehau mai ka lihilihi
Koʻili ka manu i ka pua lehua e
A inu i ka wai o ka hopoe pua
Puana ke mele o ka lehua punono
Noluehu pua hiwa i ke kiliʻohu
Hulali ka pua, ʻai ka manu i luna
Na ka ʻiʻiwi e hohoʻi mai
A inu i ka wai o ka hopoe pua
A inu i ka wai o ka pua punono
English: The mature lehua lies in the rainforest
Many birds fly amongst her branches
The ʻiʻiwi bird searches for the precious flower
The bird longs for the gorgeous lehua
The lehua is drenched in the lehua rain
The dewdrops fall from the petals
And the bird is delighted at the shine
The bird nestles into the lehua
And drinks the fully blossomed flowers nectar
Sung is the song of the gorgeous lehua
The precious flower is softened by the mist
The blossom glistens, the bird is drawn to it
It is the ʻiʻiwi bird that will always return
And drink of the lehua's nectar

Hawaiian: Kau i ka uluwehi a 'o Pana'ewa
Ke 'ike aku i ka nani o ia pua
E mukiki a kena i ka wai onaona
I ke aheahe a ka makani
A pili mau i ke aloha
Na'u no e hi'ipoe a li'a nei
I kou aloha makamae, e ku'u pua
Eia ka puana a i lohe 'ia
A'ohe ona lua e like ai
English: My Lehua of the far reaches
Dwelling in the lushness of Pana'ewa
When gazing upon the beauty of (my) sweetheart
(come) and partake and be quenched by the water
Until dizzy and overtaken with love
Swaying to and fro as if a red draped cloak
For it is my desire to always cherish (you)
For your love is precious, my sweetheart
You are always in my thoughts
Causing a stirring in my heart
Here is my story to be heard by all
My native Lehua of the far reaches
For there is no one that can compare
Forever you shall be surrounded by love

Hawaiian: I ke kulu o ke aumoe
He mele ko ka ʻiʻiwi pōlena
Halihali ʻia mai e nā manu
English: A song of the ʻiʻiwi pōlena
